<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 178, 292]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS

9702/21  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 390, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 AS Level Structured Questions  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[707, 301, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
October/November 2023  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[752, 325, 905, 341]]<|/det|>
1 hour 15 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 395, 370]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 359, 400]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 433]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 559]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 220, 602]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 729, 635]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 60.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 73, 126, 88]]<|/det|>
## Data  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 102, 688, 530]]<|/det|>
acceleration of free fall \(g = 9.81 \text{m s}^{- 2}\) speed of light in free space \(c = 3.00 \times 10^{8} \text{m s}^{- 1}\) elementary charge \(e = 1.60 \times 10^{- 19} \text{C}\) unified atomic mass unit \(1 \text{u} = 1.66 \times 10^{- 27} \text{kg}\) rest mass of proton \(m_{\mathrm{p}} = 1.67 \times 10^{- 27} \text{kg}\) rest mass of electron \(m_{\mathrm{e}} = 9.11 \times 10^{- 31} \text{kg}\) Avogadro constant \(N_{\mathrm{A}} = 6.02 \times 10^{23} \text{mol}^{- 1}\) molar gas constant \(R = 8.31 \text{J K}^{- 1} \text{mol}^{- 1}\) Boltzmann constant \(k = 1.38 \times 10^{- 23} \text{J K}^{- 1}\) gravitational constant \(G = 6.67 \times 10^{- 11} \text{N m}^{2} \text{kg}^{- 2}\) permittivity of free space \(\epsilon_{0} = 8.85 \times 10^{- 12} \text{F m}^{- 1}\) \(\left(\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}}\right) = 8.99 \times 10^{9} \text{m F}^{- 1})\) Planck constant \(h = 6.63 \times 10^{- 34} \text{J s}\) Stefan- Boltzmann constant \(\sigma = 5.67 \times 10^{- 8} \text{W m}^{- 2} \text{K}^{- 4}\)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 565, 168, 580]]<|/det|>
## Formulae

uniformly accelerated motion  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 650, 250, 666]]<|/det|>
hydrostatic pressure  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 682, 152, 698]]<|/det|>
upthrust  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 723, 339, 740]]<|/det|>
Doppler effect for sound waves  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 761, 207, 777]]<|/det|>
electric current  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 793, 228, 809]]<|/det|>
resistors in series  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 828, 238, 844]]<|/det|>
resistors in parallel

\[m_{\mathrm{p}} = 1.67\times 10^{-27}\mathrm{kg}\]

\[m_{\mathrm{e}} = 9.11\times 10^{-31}\mathrm{kg}\]

\[N_{\mathrm{A}} = 6.02\times 10^{23}\mathrm{mol}^{-1}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 317, 630, 336]]<|/det|>
\[R = 8.31\mathrm{J}\mathrm{K}^{-1}\mathrm{mol}^{-1}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 348, 640, 368]]<|/det|>
\[k = 1.38\times 10^{-23}\mathrm{J}\mathrm{K}^{-1}\]

\[G = 6.67\times 10^{-11}\mathrm{Nm}^2\mathrm{kg}^{-2}\]

\[s = ut + \frac{1}{2} at^{2}\] \[\nu^{2} = u^{2} + 2as\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 789, 606, 809]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 820, 613, 853]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{1}{R} = \frac{1}{R_{1}} +\frac{1}{R_{2}} +\ldots\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 71, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A hot-air balloon floats just above the ground. The balloon is stationary and is held in place by a vertical rope, as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[275, 116, 720, 365]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 384, 532, 403]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 415, 821, 435]]<|/det|>
The balloon has a weight \(W\) of \(3.39 \times 10^{4} \text{N}\). The tension \(T\) in the rope is \(4.00 \times 10^{2} \text{N}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 432, 376, 448]]<|/det|>
Uphtrust \(U\) acts on the balloon.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 446, 517, 465]]<|/det|>
The density of the surrounding air is \(1.23 \text{kg} \text{m}^{-3}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 477, 144, 496]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 477, 180, 496]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 477, 920, 510]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 2.1, draw labelled arrows to show the directions of the three forces acting on the balloon.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 494, 920, 512]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 523, 180, 542]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 523, 720, 542]]<|/det|>
Calculate the volume, to three significant figures, of the balloon.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[505, 693, 920, 712]]<|/det|>
<form>volume = .................................................... $\text{m}^3$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 695, 920, 712]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 725, 180, 744]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 725, 510, 744]]<|/det|>
The balloon is released from the rope.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 756, 579, 774]]<|/det|>
Calculate the initial acceleration of the balloon.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 911, 920, 929]]<|/det|>
<form>acceleration = .................................................... $\text{ms}^{-2}$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 911, 920, 929]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 148, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
The balloon is stationary at a height of \(500\mathrm{m}\) above the ground. A tennis ball is released from rest and falls vertically from the balloon.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 117, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
A passenger in the balloon uses the equation \(\nu^2 = \nu^2 + 2as\) to calculate that the ball will be travelling at a speed of approximately \(100\mathrm{m}\mathrm{s}^{- 1}\) when it hits the ground.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 165, 920, 198]]<|/det|>
Explain why the actual speed of the ball will be much lower than \(100\mathrm{m}\mathrm{s}^{- 1}\) when it hits the ground.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 303, 920, 322]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 333, 146, 352]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 333, 858, 368]]<|/det|>
Before the balloon is released, the rope holding the balloon has a strain of \(2.4 \times 10^{- 5}\). The rope has an unstretched length of \(2.5 \text{m}\). The rope obeys Hooke's law.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 381, 181, 400]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 381, 618, 400]]<|/det|>
Show that the extension of the rope is \(6.0 \times 10^{- 5} \text{m}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 490, 920, 509]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 520, 181, 539]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 520, 626, 539]]<|/det|>
Calculate the elastic potential energy \(E_{\mathrm{p}}\) of the rope.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[541, 644, 920, 663]]<|/det|>
<form>E_{\mathrm{p}} = .................................................... J

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 675, 180, 693]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 675, 920, 724]]<|/det|>
The rope holding the balloon is replaced with a new one of the same original length and cross-sectional area. The tension is unchanged and the new rope also obeys Hooke's law.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 737, 732, 755]]<|/det|>
The new rope is made from a material of a lower Young modulus.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 768, 920, 802]]<|/det|>
State and explain the effect of the lower Young modulus on the elastic potential energy of the rope.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 900, 920, 918]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[831, 908, 920, 926]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 16]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 96, 91]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|> A trolley A moves along a horizontal surface at a constant velocity towards another trolley B which is moving at a lower constant speed in the same direction. Fig. 3.1 shows the trolleys at time \(t = 0\). <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[217, 114, 777, 188]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 205, 532, 222]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 235, 421, 254]]<|/det|> Table 3.1 shows data for the trolleys. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 266, 541, 284]]<|/det|> Table 3.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[173, 297, 824, 376]]<|/det|>

B0.750.12

Resistive forces are negligible. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 418, 672, 437]]<|/det|> Fig. 3.2 shows the variation with time \(t\) of the velocity \(v\) for trolley B. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 448, 816, 808]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 827, 534, 845]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 89]]<|/det|>

Use Table 3.1 and Fig. 3.2 to determine:

<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[425, 288, 920, 307]]<|/det|>

<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 567, 910, 586]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 3.2, sketch the variation of the velocity of trolley A with time \(t\) from \(t = 0\) to \(t = 0.50 \text{s}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 584, 920, 603]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 613, 920, 632]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 9]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 72, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 448, 89]]<|/det|>
State the principle of superposition.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[858, 165, 920, 183]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 195, 146, 213]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 195, 920, 244]]<|/det|>
Coherent light is incident normally on two identical slits X and Y. The diffracted light emerging from the slits superposes to produce an interference pattern on a screen positioned at a distance of \(1.9 \text{m}\) from the slits.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 257, 920, 291]]<|/det|>
Fig. 4.1 shows the arrangement and the central part of the interference pattern of bright and dark fringes formed on the screen.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 297, 843, 536]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 553, 591, 571]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.1 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 584, 920, 617]]<|/det|>
The separation of the slits is \(0.65 \text{mm}\). The distance between the centres of adjacent bright fringes is \(1.7 \text{mm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 630, 477, 648]]<|/det|>
Calculate the wavelength \(\lambda\) of the light.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 803, 920, 821]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\lambda =\) .................................................... m [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 120]]<|/det|>
Light waves from slits X and Y in **(b)** arrive at a point between adjacent bright fringes on the screen. Fig. 4.2 shows the variation of displacement with time for the waves arriving at the point where they meet.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 128, 839, 280]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 303, 534, 322]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 336, 672, 353]]<|/det|>
A student makes two statements about the waves at this point:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 367, 685, 384]]<|/det|>
Statement 1: 'The phase difference between the waves is \(90^{\circ}\).'

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 397, 650, 415]]<|/det|>
Statement 2: 'The amplitude of the resultant wave is zero.'

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 429, 181, 448]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 429, 485, 447]]<|/det|>
Explain how statement 1 is correct.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 551, 180, 570]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 551, 598, 570]]<|/det|>
State and explain whether statement 2 is correct.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 644, 920, 662]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 675, 149, 693]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 675, 920, 708]]<|/det|>
The width of each slit in **(b)** is decreased by the same amount. There is no change to the separation of the slits.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 721, 920, 755]]<|/det|>
Describe and explain the effect, if any, of this change on the appearance of the interference pattern.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 844, 920, 863]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 861, 920, 880]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 9]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 71, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A train travels at a constant high speed along a straight horizontal track towards an observer standing adjacent to the track, as shown in Fig. 5.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[165, 118, 803, 196]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 215, 532, 234]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 5.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 246, 920, 280]]<|/det|>
The train sounds its horn continuously as it approaches the observer, from time \(t = 0\) until it is well past the observer at time \(t = t_2\). The train passes the observer at time \(t = t_1\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 277, 571, 297]]<|/det|>
The horn emits a sound wave of constant frequency \(f_{\mathrm{S}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 308, 146, 327]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 307, 920, 343]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 5.2, sketch the variation of the frequency of sound heard by the observer with time \(t\), from time \(t = 0\) to \(t = t_2\).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[312, 356, 697, 555]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 572, 534, 591]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 5.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 588, 920, 607]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 619, 146, 638]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 618, 920, 653]]<|/det|>
At a particular time, the sound waves at the observer have an intensity of \(4.7 \times 10^{-3} \text{W} \text{m}^{-2}\). The waves at the observer are incident at right angles on a circular detector of radius \(2.8 \text{cm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 666, 650, 685]]<|/det|>
Calculate the power \(P\) of the waves incident on the detector.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 854, 920, 873]]<|/det|>
<form>P = ............................................................ W [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 886, 920, 904]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A battery is connected in a circuit with a light-dependent resistor (LDR), two fixed resistors and a voltmeter, as shown in Fig. 6.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[324, 116, 670, 285]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 303, 532, 320]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 6.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
The discovery of a particle with an unusual charge was an important step in the development of the theory of quarks. The particle is a hadron with a mass of \(2.19 \times 10^{-27} \text{kg}\) and a charge of \(+2e\), where \(e\) is the elementary charge.
